reviewText:
tl;drA worth-while entry in the Kart Racer genre that is entirely over-looked because it's a Floppy Ear title! Fun for all ages and a Buy for Kart Racing enthusiasts.

full review.Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race is a cute, little Kart Racer that has more going on than you can shake a stick at.  It has several racing modes, several kart performance upgrades, plenty of unlockables from cars to characters, several difficulty levels to accomodate racers of all skill-levels and some beautiful and cartoony courses with enough variety to keep it interesting.  Best of all, it has a surprisingly solid sense of speed, which is core to any good racing game.

It's unfortunate that this game doesn't get a fair chance inspite of it's lineage; from the perspective of a single-player Kart Racer, it's pretty darn good.

There are, however, some minor problems:

First: the wonky controls.
They are soft and slippery.  They can almost feel broken when you first start playing.  But... once you adapt to the steering mechanics and adjust your driving style, you will find yourself speeding around corners and passing your competitors with ease and glee. The learning curve for me was about 45-minutes of race-time.

Second: The weird music.
And as far as the music goes, it's weird and a total mismatch for what is happening on-screen. Turn it off in the Settings and play your own up-tempo music of choice.  I played EDM and Trance for this game and it kicked up the atmosphere to eleven.

Once you disable the weirdly mismatched music and spend some time learning how to control your racer... it becomes really fun!

It's definitely no Sonic Racer, but, it's certainly better and more fun than, the albeit more polished, F1 Race All-stars.  Of all the Kart Racers on Steam, it's a worth-while one.

At full price (4,99 at the time of this review), I would recommend this for Kart Racing enthusiasts. However, if you enjoy Kart Racing and are the type of gamer who is willing to put a bit of time into learning how to steer your kart, then this is an easy Buy, especially if you get it on sale.

pros.+ Cute pseudo-paper-cutout graphics style
+ Well-designed tracks, including shortcuts
+ Beautifully cartoony tracks
+ Fun and responsive power-ups and attacks
+ Day and night tracks
+ Good AI competitors
+ Solid sense of speed
+ Split-screen, local multiplayer (I didn't test this)
+ Many unlockables (tracks, cars, characters, etc)
+ Kart performance upgrades (tires, exhaust, paint jobs, etc)
+ Full 1080P Support
+ Full Controller Support

cons.- Music is just terrible  (turn it off and play your own)
- Kart controls are sloppy, but fun once you adapt
- No online multiplayer support
- Limited graphics settings

This game is appropriate for all ages and skill-levels.

reviewText:
Delightful racing game similar to Mario Kart series. Likable characters, easy interface, nice variety of race types, etc.

The game suffers from a major flaw. It is WAY too hard for its intended audience which is children. The NPC characters are too unforgiving of mistakes and children will be frustrated. At higher difficulties and tracks, some of the races are very difficult. I am a seasoned Mario Kart player and even I have difficulty winning some races or time trials. I’m guessing it would be near impossible for younger kids, especially if they have not been brought up on keyboard only controls (see below).

99% of the races are determined by fractions of second (which makes it even odder why the developers chose to use whole second rather than hundredths), often with racers crossing the finish line at the same time.

I found the controls simple unlike many other reviewers. You basically only use A W D and the space bar with an occasional S key thrown in when you screw up and have to back up…not sure what all the fuss is. I think many Steam users are console immigrants or are not old school keyboarders (read: spoiled). The controls are fine the way they are.

While the game has cute elements and is very enjoyable, overall I cannot recommend the game as it will not appeal to its target audience.

reviewText:
Cute small cart racer for beginners.

There are 6 well-designed tracks (some have a night mode, most have a shortcut), some racing modes (single race with 4 difficulties, time trial, cone collecting, and two different tournament modes, respectively), no performance tuning, street features such as speedup arrows, a slow sand patch and a wet patch that wets your tires so that your next turn is harder to control. There are also a bunch of power-ups that speed you up or the others down (no weapons more violent than a box of thumbtacks, though). There's no story. All in all it's fairly varied.

You get two keyboard setups and you can also use one Xbox controller, which unfortunately is also all you get for split-screen. I'm calling this a beginners game because the AI and the difficulty of the challenges are no match for more experienced players once you've gotten the hang of the game (do have a look at the help before you start).  Physics are a bit strange in that you get rubber on the road long before you can hear a tire squeal, and I turned the music off after a while, but all in all it handles predictably enough for cart game physics.

I'm approximately halfway through the game, and to me it feels casual and I'm happy I didn't spend any money on it. But given the variety of race modes and tracks, it'd be a good game for a budding racing gamer - and that's precisely who it's aimed at. Recommended.

reviewText:
Are you ready for a hardcore kart combat racing game with realistic driving with a children's storybook art style? The joke is there is no joke. Teddy Floppy Ear's - The Race has a good unique look that makes it stand out from a pack of other kart racing games. The real deterrent is that its a lot tougher to play, if you take a turn too hard, you will spin out and turning feels loose in general. Perhaps that makes it a better game to play with a keyboard or a steering wheel peripheral. Because of the difficulty it misses that child demographic and falls into the men who like colorful ponies demographic.

You race in single player or two players with local split screen. Before you begin, you have your choice of fourteen anthropomorphic characters and two little girls. Its a bizarre choice to have two humans girls thrown in the mix with animals. There's no sort of indication that playing as the goat is better than the dog.

Next there is a choice of ten real world, European inspired vehicles including the Fiat, Maluch and the Trabant, with no indication of stats. You earn part upgrades by going through race seasons. You have them no matter what car you select. The only problem like the rest of the game is that without stats, its tough to feel any difference with or without them. Plus, once they're unlocked, you have them forever.

The tracks are all closed circuit courses with three laps each that last around 90 seconds for each lap. They each feel like a healthy length at under five minutes each, but any longer than that would be too much. Like other kart racers, the tracks are wide to make room for the chaos that ensues. These tracks all stay on the ground. There are no sweet jumps. At the most you'll go through a tunnel, under a bridge and then over it.

There are a few hazards to look out for, mud that will slow you down and water that's so brilliant its a true hazard. Normal kart racers would spin you out then and there, but with Teddy Floppy Ear's - The Race, the water affects when you next turn where even the slightest turn becomes harsh. If you ever drive through water, the longer you can drive forward, the safer you are. You always have brakes, but who uses those in a racing game?

The game lacks nitro and turbo, so the game is reliant on weapons. These weapons are all generic, bland and wholesome, but its what you want for a kids game. You run through hovering weapon icons each with their own color. White milk, yellow lemonade, maroon mud, cyan tacks, purple kibble, red fire extinguisher and blue boots. Milk makes you grow larger so you can flatten enemies if you're going fast enough. The only problem is that you're so large it becomes easy to tumble over and roll sideways. The fire extinguisher and kibble both seem to do the same thing which is a radial explosion that either pushes or tumbles over adversaries. The tacks spray a hard-to-see bed of tacks. Mud makes a mud puddle to slow down drivers, the lemonade does just about the same thing and the boots let you drive through any hazard. The mud, demimondaine and boots each give you a short nitro boost. Someone thought it would be a good idea for animals to leave pools of yellow and brown liquid on the track.

One of the best risk or reward mechanics in the game is having single weapons alone next to kiosks. Ninety-nine percent of the time you can grab the weapon just fine, but its that one percent that has you colliding into the stand. There is a respawn button, but it drops you from a bit high so its a few second penalty for using it.

The bulk of the game is short, two hours spread across four seasons with five tracks that each have a day and night to make them feel different. Three of the closed circuit tracks blend together while the castle and town feel beautiful and a fresh take with the art style. Night races are dark and only challenging because its tougher to see. There are lights and lanterns, but going over bridges and some other areas, they've been forgotten about.

There is no difficulty setting for the seasons. Instead the earlier seasons start with three tracks and the latter ones have more. It never felt like the later championships were any more difficult than the earlier ones. There are four difficulty levels for single races.

To keep you in the game there is a collector's slalom which has you collecting stars along a path. Collecting over eighty percent grants you a voucher for a free vehicle. Collect all five and you unlock the new vehicle. This feels like a great mode to increase the game's longevity without having too much development time. It sure beats having only a time trial.

Then you have the floppy cups which are tournament races where you go one-on-one against drivers. It just feels dull in a kart combat game to only have one racer. It also looks awkward when I'm the winner standing alone on top of a podium meant for three.

The unsung hero is the music. Its noticeable how soothing it is with a good light beat and melody. Its rare to find flutes in video game music let alone a racer.

Its a definite toss up whether to recommend the game. Its worth the cheap five dollar price tag for the two hours and whatever else you can garner from the game. It feels like the driving should have been more typical when it comes to a kid's game. Plus there should really be a kid's auto drive mode that mobile phone games seem to have. Its a game worth having a sequel for its style.

reviewText:
- the good -
It's a fun little racer. The handling doesn't feel as crisp as other, more well-known kart racing games. But it kind of adds to the charm and makes every kart game unique.

The game tries to remain interesting by unlocking some new cars and car upgrades (visual only, I think). But there isn't anything more than that.

- the bad -
While there are several modes, such as a tournament knock-out mode, league, time trial and single race, there are very few tracks to play those modes on. The time I spent (4 hours at the time of writing this review), is all the time needed to get all achievements for this game. You can probably do it in less, especially if you don't care for the trading cards.

- the ugly -
As I said, handling can be a little bit awkward, but is manageable. But physics can be really painful sometimes. When you are going to fast cars will start wobbling. When you are making a turn you have the chance of toppling over. I don't know if this is intentional or just a problem with the physics configuration, but it feels cheap and annoying.

- the verdict -
If any of these characters have some nostalgic meaning to them, go for it. If you are looking for a fun kart game I recommend to look elsewhere. I definitely recommend SuperTuxKart if you haven't already ;)

reviewText:
An excellent game that provided me hours of fun (adult). This game has pleasant aesthetics, does not suffer from major bugs, and provides a little bit of challenge to complete the races.

The controls are slippery, but not the bad kind of slippery; it is part of the game to be able to master it (which only takes 2-3 races).

Here are some bugs I've noticed:
- AI only moves forward, so sometimes they get trapped and you need to bump into them so that they can go back to the race.
- AI doesn't usually take the shortcuts (only when forced, by bumping into them), but they should on expert difficulty.
- The middle of the city stage has a problem on the rank system, so even if you are half a lap in front of everybody you will keep changing positions with everybody until you are out of the buggy zone.
- Twice I was racing (I think it was on the last stage) and one of the enemies got stuck out of stage (one of these times I was smashed, and the one who smashed me ran over me and ended up outside of stage). They wouldn't come back.

Improvement points:
- Add online multiplayer
- Add manual drift
- Add more stages; it gets boring to play the same thing over and over.
- I'd always avoid the milk bottles, as they are almost always a problem than a solution; when you hit someone you smash them, but you usually get thrown somewhere else, or even flip over, making every other player pass you. Maybe they should be removed or improved somehow?

Anyway, awesome game, and I'm looking forward to the Teddy Floppy Ear - The Race 2.

Note: Put the Diddy Kong Racing OST on the background and have fun.

reviewText:
- the good -
It's a fun little racer. The handling doesn't feel as crisp as other, more well-known kart racing games. But it kind of adds to the charm and makes every kart game unique.

The game tries to remain interesting by unlocking some new cars and car upgrades (visual only, I think). But there isn't anything more than that.

- the bad -
While there are several modes, such as a tournament knock-out mode, league, time trial and single race, there are very few tracks to play those modes on. The time I spent (4 hours at the time of writing this review), is all the time needed to get all achievements for this game. You can probably do it in less, especially if you don't care for the trading cards.

- the ugly -
As I said, handling can be a little bit awkward, but is manageable. But physics can be really painful sometimes. When you are going to fast cars will start wobbling. When you are making a turn you have the chance of toppling over. I don't know if this is intentional or just a problem with the physics configuration, but it feels cheap and annoying.

- the verdict -
If any of these characters have some nostalgic meaning to them, go for it. If you are looking for a fun kart game I recommend to look elsewhere. I definitely recommend SuperTuxKart if you haven't already ;)
